message.content:
<teammate-message teammate_id="team-lead" summary="Rate Editor profile items 1-10 priority">
PRIORITY SCORING: Rate each item in the Editor profile on a scale of 1-10 (10 = absolutely critical, 1 = barely relevant).

**CORE SKILLS — rate each:**
S1. Native-level English prose craft with experience editing translated philosophical texts
S2. Sensitivity to 5 registers (colloquial/thinking-aloud, analytic, classical quotation, mathematical/formal, near-lyrical) and their transitions
S3. Ear for experiential pacing — sequences are philosophical experiments on the reader, prose rhythm is load-bearing
S4. Ability to distinguish productive strangeness from translationese
S5. Ability to distinguish necessary density from unnecessary opacity

**RESPONSIBILITIES — rate each:**
R1. Prose quality: sentence rhythm, paragraph flow, readability
R2. Cross-essay register and voice consistency
R3. Flag ambiguous pronoun references, awkward constructions, Chinese syntax bleedthrough
R4. Ensure glossing conventions applied consistently (first-occurrence format, re-gloss rules)
R5. Ensure emphasis markers (bold/italic) used consistently per source
R6. Verify footnote/TN integration doesn't break experiential momentum
R7. Flag passages where translation is accurate but experientially flat
R8. Check logical connectives signal the right argumentative direction

**BOUNDARIES — rate each (10 = absolutely must enforce, 1 = flexible):**
B1. NOT alter terminology from the Translation Dictionary
B2. NOT restructure or reorder arguments/examples
B3. NOT resolve deliberate ambiguity
B4. NOT polish away working-draft quality (todos, hedges, self-corrections)
B5. NOT add explanatory content (flag for translator/experts instead)
B6. NOT harmonize Essay 2's native English with translated essays
B7. NOT impose uniform house style across registers
B8. NOT adjudicate philosophical disputes — escalate to experts
B9. NOT smooth away intentional repetition (e.g., "phenomenal X" prefix)

Reply in this format:
S1:[score] S2:[score] S3:[score] S4:[score] S5:[score]
R1:[score] R2:[score] R3:[score] R4:[score] R5:[score] R6:[score] R7:[score] R8:[score]
B1:[score] B2:[score] B3:[score] B4:[score] B5:[score] B6:[score] B7:[score] B8:[score] B9:[score]
</teammate-message>

input.content:
S1:9 S2:10 S3:9 S4:10 S5:9
R1:9 R2:8 R3:8 R4:7 R5:6 R6:9 R7:10 R8:9
B1:10 B2:10 B3:10 B4:8 B5:9 B6:7 B7:9 B8:10 B9:10

Brief justifications for my highest and most distinctive scores:

S2:10 — The register shifts are not decorative; they track the author's movement between modes of thought. The 零散想法 essay alone moves from analytical argument to coin-flip phenomenology to near-lyrical crescendo. An Editor who can't hear these transitions will flatten the work's most distinctive quality.

S4:10 — This is the single most important editorial judgment call. The author's prose *should* feel unfamiliar in places — the phenomenological reversal structure, the way concepts get constructed bottom-up — that strangeness is philosophical content. An Editor who normalizes it destroys what makes the work original. But actual translationese (Chinese syntax bleedthrough, awkward calques) must go. Drawing that line is the Editor's core competence.

R7:10 — From an existentialist perspective, this text is meant to produce experiences in the reader, not just convey propositions. The 道德仁义礼 passage should feel like a vertiginous reversal. If the translation is accurate but experientially dead, it has failed. This is the one thing only a prose Editor can catch — we experts check accuracy, but we can become blind to flatness because we already know what the sentence is supposed to do.

B3:10 — The author deliberately leaves certain things unresolved (e.g., whether 境 construction is always successful, the status of the "paper on which a painting is made" metaphor for 道). These open spaces are philosophically functional — they invite the reader into the thinking. Closing them is not editing; it's rewriting.

B9:10 — "Phenomenal X" repetition is terminological, not stylistic. It marks the author's systematic distinction between phenomena-level instances and their metaphysical counterparts. An Editor who varies it for prose elegance would undermine the entire conceptual architecture.
input.summary: Priority scores with justifications for key ratings

content.text:
Submitted my priority scores with justifications for the most critical ratings. The items I rated highest (all 10s) reflect the core concerns from an existentialist perspective:

- **S2 (register sensitivity)** and **S4 (productive strangeness vs. translationese)** as the most critical skills
- **R7 (flagging experientially flat passages)** as the most important responsibility — this text is meant to produce philosophical experiences, not just convey information
- **B3 (don't resolve ambiguity)**, **B9 (don't smooth "phenomenal X" repetition)**, **B1 (don't alter terminology)**, **B2 (don't restructure arguments)**, and **B8 (don't adjudicate philosophy)** as the hardest boundaries to enforce
